prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A student working part-time at the offices of Edgeworth and Co. Studying to be an attorney.
Character 1
Name: Samson Tangaroa
Description: My client, and a man said to be the greatest confectioner of his generation.
Character 2
Name: Artie Frost
Description: The murder victim. Found dead inside Samson Tangaroa's chocolate work.
Character 3
Name: Judy Bound
Description: Assistant to Samson Tangaroa. She's fond of the work of sculptor Paul Halique.
Character 4
Name: Tyrell Badd
Description: The detective assigned to this case. A man of few words.
Character 5
Name: Carmelo Gusto
Description: A candy-crafting confectioner who's taking part in the contest.
Character 6
Name: Delicia Scone
Description: A confectioner who will do whatever it takes to achieve her goals.
Character 7
Name: Manfred von Karma
Description: The prosecutor in charge of this case. It is said that he has never lost a trial in these past 25 years.
Character 8
Name: Laurice Deauxnim
Description: Pseudonym of Larry Butz, my friend since childhood. He fancies himself as something of an artist.
Character 9
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 10
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 11
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 12
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: The greatest prosecutor ever to prosecute... according to himself, anyway. In actual fact, his relationship with logic is tenuous at best.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. Polishing it every day has become just another part of my daily routine.
Evidence 1
Name: Seal
Description: A seal that was found near the body when it was discovered. What could the design signify?
Evidence 2
Name: Crime Scene Notes
Description: Notes about the crime scene. The police have taken custody of the body. [info] The victim's body found in Samson Tangaroa's room, inside a chocolate treasure chest. The cause of death appears to have been blood loss following blunt force trauma. [caption] The victim's body is curled inside a chest crushed by a ship post. The body is half covered by a blue sheet. There is a silver coin next to the body.
Evidence 3
Name: Mr. Tangaroa's Teapot
Description: A Paul Halique piece with Tangaroa's fingerprints on it.
Evidence 4
Name: Contest Rules
Description: A piece of paper listing the rules for the contest.
Evidence 5
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Someone left finger marks on the chocolate frame, but didn't leave any prints.
Evidence 6
Name: Mansion Key
Description: The one and only key that unlocks every door in the mansion. Tangaroa was in possession of it the entire time.
Evidence 7
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: Salt lamp found in Scone's room. Stained with the victim's blood.
Evidence 8
Name: Fake Confections
Description: Ms. Scone's so-called creations were all fake plastic models, covered in a thick layer of whipped cream.
Evidence 9
Name: Chocolates
Description: Tangaroa's favorite, handmade by Bound. Rather misshapened, and incredibly sweet.
Evidence 10
Name: Instant Camera
Description: Takes photos that develop instantly. A new film cartridge has twenty exposures, but there are only three remaining.
Evidence 11
Name: Mr. Frost's Room
Description: A photo of Frost's sculptures, taken by Judy Bound. Two photos, one from Bound and one from Detective Badd.
Evidence 12
Name: Ms. Scone's Statement
Description: Frost's sculptures were "scrumptious", except for the lyre, which was salty.
Evidence 13
Name: Semifinal Entries
Description: Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs, but tasted the same.
Evidence 14
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 15
Name: Victim's Blood
Description: Frost's blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 16
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 17
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 18
Name: IS-7 Incident Case File
Description: Documents providing an overview of the IS-7 Incident. Documents received from Fender, including his comments in red.
Evidence 19
Name: Gallery Pamphlet
Description: A pamphlet received upon entry to the gallery.
Evidence 20
Name: Winter Wing Photo
Description: Statues matching those made by the victim eighteen years ago.
Evidence 21
Name: Pisces Statue Sketch
Description: A sketch by Larry depicting the Pisces statue exactly as he saw it.
Evidence 22
Name: Used Blowtorch
Description: There are signs it was used just before the police arrived. Possibly to heat something?
Evidence 23
Name: Luminous Cloth
Description: Cloth that glows when connected to a full-spectrum light-emitting device. [caption] Looks like a blue sheet. Delicia Scone's property. One of these was lost eighteen years ago. Given to Bound by Scone. Lost eighteen years ago, only to be rediscovered floating in the fountain.
Evidence 24
Name: Poison Gas Ingredients
Description: The gas was produced when bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion were mixed together.
Evidence 25
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 26
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Finger marks left by someone in Tangaroa's room. No accompanying prints.
Evidence 27
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: A photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident. It's a salt lamp stained with Frost's blood.
Evidence 28
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 29
Name: Teapot
Description: Designed by Paul Halique. One of Judy Bound's prize possessions.
Evidence 30
Name: Ceramic Fragment
Description: Found in a puddle of tea. The design looks familiar.
Evidence 31
Name: Lift Cart
Description: Used by Frost to transport ice eighteen years ago. The top of the platform is wet.
Evidence 32
Name: Larry's Sketches
Description: Sketches depicting exactly what Larry saw.
Evidence 33
Name: Gemini Case Analysis Results
Description: Results of the analysis conducted on the melted contents of the Gemini case.
Evidence 34
Name: Chocolates
Description: Handmade by Bound. Slightly melted after being kept in her pocket.
Evidence 35
Name: Statute of Limitations
Description: A book explaining the statutes of limitations of various crimes.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: If the body had been found in a locked room... Master would've been the prime suspect.
Person: Badd
Testimony 1
Testimony: That's why Master made sure to leave the door to his own room unlocked...
Person: Badd
Testimony 2
Testimony: And to ensure that the body would be seen... Master broke the lid on the treasure chest.
Person: Badd
Testimony 3
Testimony: After the judging... everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room...
Person: Badd
Testimony 4
Testimony: That would have created the impression... that the murder had occurred... while he was away.
Person: Badd

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. Let's start by looking at the testimonies first. The testimonies here are from Badd. The user provided Testimony 0 to Testimony 4, all from Badd. 

Looking at Testimony 0: "If the body had been found in a locked room... Master would've been the prime suspect." The "Master" here probably refers to Samson Tangaroa, since he's the client. Badd is saying that if the room was locked, Tangaroa would be the main suspect because he had the key, maybe?

Testimony 1: "That's why Master made sure to leave the door to his own room unlocked..." So according to Badd, Tangaroa left his door unlocked to avoid being the prime suspect in a locked room scenario.

Testimony 2: "And to ensure that the body would be seen... Master broke the lid on the treasure chest." So breaking the lid would make the body visible, implying that the body was hidden inside the chest otherwise.

Testimony 3: "After the judging... everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room..." This might be about the timeline or alibi.

Testimony 4: "That would have created the impression... that the murder had occurred... while he was away." So Tangaroa wanted it to look like the murder happened when he wasn't there.

Now, looking at the evidences. Let's go through them to find something that contradicts any of these testimonies.

Evidence 2: "Crime Scene Notes" says the victim's body was found inside a chocolate treasure chest, and the cause of death was blood loss from blunt force trauma. The notes mention the body was curled inside a chest crushed by a ship post, covered by a blue sheet, and there's a silver coin next to the body. 

Wait, Testimony 2 says that Tangaroa broke the lid to ensure the body was seen. But according to the crime scene notes, the body was already inside the chest, but maybe the lid was broken to make it visible. However, the evidence doesn't explicitly say whether the lid was broken or not. Hmm, maybe not the best contradiction here.

Looking further: Evidence 6 is "Mansion Key" which states that Tangaroa was in possession of the key the entire time. The key unlocks every door. 

If Testimony 1 says Tangaroa left his door unlocked to avoid being the prime suspect in a locked room scenario, then the key being in his possession supports that he could have locked or unlocked his room. But does that contradict anything? Maybe not directly.

Evidence 23: "Luminous Cloth" is described as a blue sheet that glows when connected to a light device. The caption says it's one of Delicia Scone's properties, and it was lost eighteen years ago but found in the fountain. The cloth was used to cover the body in the crime scene (since the crime scene notes mention a blue sheet). 

Wait, if the blue sheet (Luminous Cloth) was found at the scene, but according to Testimony 2, Tangaroa broke the lid to make the body visible, then maybe the cloth was covering the body. If the cloth was Scone's, then maybe someone else used it. But how does this contradict?

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 22: "Used Blowtorch" which was used just before the police arrived. Maybe the blowtorch was used to melt something, like the chocolate chest? If the chest was melted open, that would contradict the idea that Tangaroa broke the lid. 

Wait, Testimony 2 says "Master broke the lid on the treasure chest." If the blowtorch was used, then the lid might have been melted open, not broken manually. That would mean the method of opening the chest was different than what Badd is testifying. 

So, Testimony 2 claims Tangaroa broke the lid, but if the evidence (Evidence 22) shows that a blowtorch was used, which implies the lid was melted open, then that contradicts the testimony. 

Alternatively, Evidence 22's description says "possibly to heat something?" which might relate to melting the chest. If the blowtorch was used to open the chest, then the breaking wasn't done manually by Tangaroa, which would contradict Badd's testimony that Tangaroa broke it. 

Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 22 (Used Blowtorch) and Testimony 2. 

Wait, but let me check other possibilities. Evidence 26 is "Frame Finger Marks" which mentions finger marks on the chocolate frame but no prints. Maybe that's about someone wearing gloves, but not sure.

Alternatively, Evidence 27 is "Salt Lamp" which is the murder weapon from the IS-7 incident, stained with Frost's blood. If the murder weapon was a salt lamp, then maybe the blunt force trauma was caused by that. But how does that relate to the testimony?

Alternatively, looking back at Testimony 4: Badd says that the setup made it look like the murder happened while Tangaroa was away. If the time of death or the presence of Tangaroa's key (Evidence 6) shows he was there, but that might not directly contradict.

Hmm. Let me re-examine Testimony 2 again. Testimony 2 says that Master (Tangaroa) broke the lid to ensure the body was seen. If the lid was actually melted open by a blowtorch (Evidence 22), that's a different method than "breaking" it manually. So the evidence suggests a tool was used, contradicting the testimony's claim that Tangaroa broke it himself. Therefore, Evidence 22 contradicts Testimony 2.
</think>

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: In order to pin the crime on Delicia, Master used the rock salt lamp to kill the victim.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 1
Testimony: He then deposited the murder weapon in Delicia's room.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 2
Testimony: If he had left the murder weapon at the crime scene, Master would have been the one suspected.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 3
Testimony: He couldn't move the body, but it was easy to move the murder weapon.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 4
Testimony: Ergo, there would be no evidence pointing to a specific culprit at the crime scene.
Person: von Karma

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see what I need to do here. The user has provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies related to a murder case. My task is to find a pair where an evidence contradicts a testimony. The answer should be in JSON format with the evidence number and testimony number, and I have to make sure only one pair is given.

First, I need to go through each evidence and testimony carefully to spot any contradictions. Let me start by reviewing the testimonies first to understand what each is claiming, then check the evidences against them.

Looking at the testimonies from von Karma:

Testimony 0: "In order to pin the crime on Delicia, Master used the rock salt lamp to kill the victim."
Testimony 1: "He then deposited the murder weapon in Delicia's room."
Testimony 2: "If he had left the murder weapon at the crime scene, Master would have been the one suspected."
Testimony 3: "He couldn't move the body, but it was easy to move the murder weapon."
Testimony 4: "Ergo, there would be no evidence pointing to a specific culprit at the crime scene."

Now, let me look at the evidences. Evidence 7 is "Salt Lamp" described as "Salt lamp found in Scone's room. Stained with the victim's blood." So according to evidence 7, the salt lamp was indeed found in Delicia Scone's room and has the victim's blood. That seems to support part of von Karma's testimony where he says the weapon was placed there to frame her. But wait, maybe there's a contradiction elsewhere?

Another evidence is Evidence 27: "Salt Lamp: A photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident. It's a salt lamp stained with Frost's blood." Hmm, maybe that's the same as evidence 7? Wait, looking again, the user provided duplicate entries for some evidences. Evidence 7 and 27 both mention salt lamps, but maybe they are different? Let me check. Evidence 27 says it's from the IS-7 Incident, which might be a previous case. But the description mentions Frost's blood, so perhaps it's the same as evidence 7. However, the key point here is that von Karma claims the murder weapon (the salt lamp) was moved to Delicia's room. The evidence states that the salt lamp was indeed found in her room, which aligns with his testimony. So that's not a contradiction.

Wait, but let me check other evidences. Evidence 22 is "Used Blowtorch: There are signs it was used just before the police arrived. Possibly to heat something?" Maybe the blowtorch is related? But von Karma didn't mention a blowtorch.

Another angle: Testimony 3 says the body couldn't be moved, so the murder weapon must have been moved. Evidence 2 says the victim was found inside a chocolate treasure chest in Tangaroa's room. So if the body was there, moving it would be hard. But does any evidence contradict that the body was moved?

Looking at Evidence 23: "Luminous Cloth: Cloth that glows... Given to Bound by Scone. Lost eighteen years ago, only to be rediscovered floating in the fountain." Wait, the cloth was found in the fountain. If the body was in Tangaroa's room, but the cloth (used to cover the body?) was found in the fountain, maybe that suggests the body was moved? But the crime scene notes (Evidence 2) say the body was found in Tangaroa's room. So maybe the cloth was moved, but the body wasn't? Not sure if that's a contradiction.

Wait, Testimony 3 says "He couldn't move the body, but it was easy to move the murder weapon." If the body was found where it was killed, then that's okay. But if there's evidence that the body was moved, that would contradict. However, Evidence 15 says "Victim's Blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime." So blood is in the fountain but not at the crime scene. That suggests the body was moved, because the scene has no blood? Wait, the crime scene notes (Evidence 2) say the body was in the chest, and there's blood loss. If blood is missing from the scene but found elsewhere, maybe the body was moved. That would contradict Testimony 3's claim that the body couldn't be moved. 

Wait, Testimony 3 says "He couldn't move the body, but it was easy to move the murder weapon." If the blood is found in the fountain, that implies the body was moved there, but according to the crime scene notes, the body was found in Tangaroa's room. Wait, that's conflicting. Wait, the crime scene notes say the body was found in Tangaroa's room, but the blood is in the fountain. So maybe the body was moved from the fountain to the room? But that would mean the body was moved, contradicting von Karma's testimony that the body couldn't be moved. 

Alternatively, maybe the blood in the fountain is from another source. Let me recheck Evidence 15: "Victim's Blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime." So the scene (Tangaroa's room) has no blood, but the fountain does. That suggests that the victim was at the fountain first, then moved to the room. So the body was moved, which contradicts von Karma's Testimony 3 which says the body couldn't be moved. 

So the contradiction is between Evidence 15 and Testimony 3. Let me check the numbers. Evidence 15 is the Victim's Blood in the fountain, and Testimony 3 is testimony number 3. 

Wait, the user's instruction says to output only one pair, so I need to make sure. The user's previous examples had similar structures. So the correct pair would be evidence 15 and testimony 3. 

Wait, but let me confirm once more. Testimony 3 says the body couldn't be moved, so the murder weapon was moved instead. But if the victim's blood is found in the fountain, which is a different location from the crime scene (Tangaroa's room), that implies the body was moved from the fountain to the room, hence the body was moved, contradicting Testimony 3's claim that it couldn't be moved. 

Therefore, the answer should be {"evidence": 15, "testimony": 3}.
</think>
